TEXT.citation: Indosan, S., Wakelin, G., Dararyaw, S., and Kalaku, S. (1958). Yami texts. Work Papers of the Summer Institute of Linguistics, University of North Dakota Session: Vol. 2, Article 7. 10.31356/silwp.vol02.07
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @article{indosan1958yami, title={Yami texts}, year={1958}, author={Indosan, Samen and Wakelin, Grace and Dararyaw, Sinan and Kalaku, Saman}, journal={Work Papers of the Summer Institute of Linguistics, University of North Dakota Session}, volume={2}, number={7}, doi={10.31356/silwp.vol02.07}

S.FORM: m-angay-ta lu takay mang-anak-u kwan-a ina-na
S.TRANSL: "Let us both go to the field, my child," said his mother.
She went to dig for gold.
She said to the child, "Come here." The mother goes.
The child sees the spirit take the mother up to the sky.

S.FORM: lavi a nu anak-na s-ina-na k-auli-na
S.TRANSL: The child cries, "Mother, return!"
"Where is your mother?" said his father.
"Mother isn't here," he replied.
"The spirit crept up and flew away with Mother."

S.FORM: mang-ep su aru nu varit/yaked s-ama-na kavangepna?
S.TRANSL: The father took many strips of bamboo,

S.FORM: k-angay-na lu tatala katukad-na lu kwang
S.TRANSL: went to the boat, and sailed far away.

S.FORM: m-angay lu ilaud m-angay lu vagay nu kwaway
S.TRANSL: They went to a foreign country to the spirit's house.

S.FORM: lu kwang chitagen-a u aru nu tau
S.TRANSL: Far away, they saw many people.
They saw his house in the foreign country.
"You go home to your own people,"

S.FORM: kwan-a karwan nu tau lu ilaud
S.TRANSL: said the foreigner.

S.FORM: ku-mi-chitagen nu mavakes-ku naket-na nu kwaway
S.TRANSL: "I see the spirit captured my wife."

S.FORM: m-angay-ka lu makarang nu tukun kwan-a nu tau
S.TRANSL: "You go to the stilt house on the mountain," the foreigner said,
"and see there how your wife is being cared for."
"Who are you coming here to look for your mother?

S.FORM: nak-nakem-ku-inyu? anak nu yamen lu yami
S.TRANSL: I think that you are a child of us Yami people.
I wonder if you are really our child, dear.
If I wash

S.FORM: su pasavuren-ku dinwen nu maumlesan su chinwat-an
S.TRANSL: you with boiling water
and your skin peels off,
then you are not our child."
She washed him and the child was fine, so she said, "You are really our child."
The spirit's wing was burned.
"Let's go and see them catching fish."
She made a hat, and went

S.FORM: nu vagay-na nu apia nu k-anak-an
S.TRANSL: to the child's good house.
"You are going, dear child," said his mother.

S.FORM: m-angay-ka chyaa? nu apia tau kwan
S.TRANSL: It doesn't matter if you do go. They are good people over there.

S.FORM: apia nun m-angay-ku-rana kwan m-angay kalilyan u vaunda
S.TRANSL: "Yes, good people; so I'll go," he said, and went to the plain (where the mother had been taken up).
The child cries, "You are so very tall. (unctn)
I'm afraid, because I'm just little."(unctn)
"Come here, dear little one."
"I don't want to; I am not going, because Mother will scold us.

S.FORM: y-abu m-angay-ku mwama tu kungyan avay-aken ina
S.TRANSL: I'm not going to do planting in the mountains. Mother will scold me.
I'm going to look for something here in the trees."
"Come here, dear."
"I don't want to," he said.
"Then I'll cut off your mother's head. That's why I'm going."
"I don't want you to. I musn't let mother's head be cut off.
Cut off a goat's head."
"Come here, dear.
I'm going to cut off your mother's head."
"Yes," and the child began to cry.
After five days, he cut off her head.
(cut unan neck)unctn
She couldn't move
or bear children any more.
The husband wailed,
and cried, "Your mother's blood is flowing down.
Don't bury her."
They went home and combed their hair
and prepared the vegetables
while the husband cried.
He saw the mother's spirit, and she said, "You were not bad.
My head was cut off and are you crying?
Look at me." "Let us both go,"
said her husband.
"Excuse me, Machinara, I'm going to sit by our betel nut basket.
